Correlation among preparation methods/conditions, physicochemical properties, and catalytic performance of Rh/hydroxyapatite catalysts in N2O decomposition Chengyun Huang a Yixiang Jiang a Zhen Ma b ⁎ Pengfei Xie a Yi Lin b Tao Meng b Changxi Miao c ⁎ Yinghong Yue a Weiming Hua a ⁎ Zi Gao a a Shanghai Key Laboratory of Molecular Catalysis and Innovative Materials, Department of Chemistry, Fudan University, Shanghai, 200433, PR China Shanghai Key Laboratory of Molecular Catalysis and Innovative Materials Department of Chemistry Fudan University Shanghai 200433 PR China b Shanghai Key Laboratory of Atmospheric Particle Pollution and Prevention (LAP3), Department of Environmental Science and Engineering, Fudan University, Shanghai, 200433, PR China Shanghai Key Laboratory of Atmospheric Particle Pollution and Prevention (LAP3) Department of Environmental Science and Engineering Fudan University Shanghai 200433 PR China c Shanghai Research Institute of Petrochemical Technology SINOPEC, Shanghai, 201208, PR China Shanghai Research Institute of Petrochemical Technology SINOPEC Shanghai 201208 PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract Three hydroxyapatite (HAP) supported rhodium catalysts (i.e., Rh/HAP-PEG-200, Rh/HAP-EDTA-200, and Rh/HAP-EDTA-100) were prepared by loading Rh(NO3)3 onto HAP supports prepared hydrothermally at 200 or 100°C in the presence of PEG or EDTA additive, followed by calcination at 500°C. For comparison, an additional Rh/HAP-normal catalyst was prepared using a conventional HAP support prepared by precipitation. Different preparation methods/conditions were found to influence the physicochemical properties (e.g., micro-morphology, basicity, concentration of surface hydroxyls, oxygen-desorption property) of HAP supports and/or Rh/HAP catalysts. The activities of these catalysts in N2O decomposition follow the sequence of Rh/HAP-PEG-200>Rh/HAP-EDTA-200≈Rh/HAP-normal>Rh/EDTA-100. The correlation among preparation methods/conditions, physicochemical properties, and catalytic performance of Rh/HAP catalysts was investigated in detail. Keywords N2O decomposition Hydroxyapatite Rhodium Micro-morphology Hydrothermal synthesis 1 Introduction Hydroxyapatite (HAP), with a stoichiometric formula of Ca10(PO4)6(OH)2, has high thermal stability, moderate acidity and basicity, and rich surface hydroxyls. In addition, its physicochemical properties can be adjusted by introducing atomic defects [1] or via ion exchange [2]. These characteristics make HAP useful as a catalyst in organic reactions, conversion of ethanol [1,3], Knoevenagel condensation [4], aldol condensation [5], Michael addition [6], acrylic acid synthesis from lactic acid [7], photocatalytic degradation of calmagite [8], and formaldehyde combustion [9]. The ion-exchange capacity of HAP and strong interaction between HAP and gust species make HAP useful as a catalyst support or host material. For instance, Co-exchanged HAP exhibits good performance in the oxidative dehydrogenation of 2-butanol and ethane [10]. Zn-substituted HAP is active for 2-propanol decomposition [11]. Cu-exchanged HAP is active for formaldehyde oxidation [12], Glaser-Hay CC homo-coupling of terminal alkynes [13], and selective catalytic reduction of NOx [2,14]. Au/HAP can catalyze CO oxidation [15–17], the water-gas shift reaction [18], and organic synthesis [19,20]. In our previous study, Rh/HAP was found to be very active for N2O decomposition [21]. Aside from the conventional precipitation method, novel synthesis methods such as conversion of solid precursors [22,23], sol-gel [24,25], hydrothermal [26,27], reverse microemulsion [28,29], ultrasonic irradiation [30,31], rapid combustion [32,33], and biogenic sources synthesis [34], have been used to prepare HAP materials with different properties. For example, HAP hollow nanoparticles prepared by polymeric micelle-templated [35] and sol-gel [36] methods showed better drug delivery performance than micrometer-scale HAP prepared by co-precipitation. HAP nanopowders prepared by a sol-gel method have superior bioresorption than commercial HAP and biological HAP [37]. In addition, HAP synthesized by hydrothermal crystallization promotes in situ catalytic upgrading of biocrude products [38]. N2O decomposition is an important reaction of environmental relevance because N2O is a potent greenhouse gas and it also contributes to ozone layer depletion. Catalysts used for this reaction can be classified into supported noble metals, pure and mixed metal oxides, and zeolite-based catalysts [39,40]. Rh-based catalysts often exhibit high activity at relatively low reaction temperatures [41–43], thus attracting much attention. Rh-based catalysts used for N2O decomposition include Rh/Al2O3 [41,42], Rh/CeO2 [42,44], Rh/ZnO [45], Rh/MgO [46], Rh/USY [47], and Rh/SBA-15 [43,48,49]. The properties of supports play an important role in determining the catalytic activity [21,45,46]. Preparation conditions (such as Rh precursors [47,48] and deposition methods [49]) and the modification of supports [50–53] may also influence the activity. The influence of co-feed gases (such as O2 [42,54], H2O [50,54], NO [55,56], and SO2 [57,58]) and the reaction mechanism [42,59,60] have also been reported. However, most of these references focus on Rh supported on metal oxides or zeolites, whereas Rh supported on metal phosphates was rarely reported. In a recent work, Rh/HAP prepared by using a commercial HAP support was found to be much more active in N2O decomposition than Rh supported on other metal phosphates [54]. The influence of pH value during the synthesis of HAP support by precipitation and the effect of pretreatment ambient on the performance of Rh/HAP were studied [21]. Rh/HAP was found to be much more active than Rh/SiO2, Rh/Al2O3, and Rh/TiO2 [21], and in general more active than metal oxides [61,62] and zeolite-based catalysts [63–67]. There is no research dealing with the correlation among different preparation methods, physicochemical properties, and catalytic performance of Rh/HAP in N2O decomposition. In the current work, a series of HAP-supported Rh catalysts, (i.e., Rh/HAP-PEG-200, Rh/HAP-EDTA-200, and Rh/HAP-EDTA-100) were prepared by using HAP supports synthesized hydrothermally in the presence of different additives. For comparison, Rh/HAP-normal was prepared by using HAP prepared by precipitation. Interestingly, these catalysts showed different catalytic activities in N2O decomposition. The correlation among preparation methods/conditions, physicochemical properties (e.g., micro-morphology, basicity, concentration of surface hydroxyls, oxygen-desorption property), and catalytic performance was established. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation HAP supports were prepared via a hydrothermal method [26,68]. In a typical synthesis, 9.45g Ca(NO3)2•4H2O and an additive (0.2g PEG600 or 8.93g Na2-EDTA) were dissolved in 40mL distilled water. Here PEG-600 refers to polyethylene glycol 600, and Na2-EDTA refers to ethylene diamine tetraacetic acid disodium. An aqueous (NH4)2HPO4 solution (3.17g (NH4)2HPO4 dissolved in 60mL distilled water) was added dropwise (2mLmin−1) to the former solution under stirring at room temperature. Afterwards, aqueous ammonia (25wt.%) was added till pH 10.5. The mixture was aged at room temperature for 0.5h, transferred to a Teflon-lined autoclave container (200mL), and heated at 100 or 200°C for 24h. The precipitates were isolated by centrifugation, thoroughly washed by deionized water, dried at 100°C overnight, and calcined in a muffle furnace at 500°C for 4h under flowing air. The HAP samples are referred to as HAP-X-Y, where X represents the additive and Y the hydrothermal temperature. For comparison, a conventional HAP sample (HAP-normal) was synthesized by precipitation. The preparation procedure was similar to the one described above, expect that the mixture obtained after adding aqueous ammonia (to adjust the pH value to 10.5) was aged at 80°C for 2h and no additive was added. Rhodium was loaded onto HAP supports by impregnation. 1.98g HAP was mixed with 10mL Rh(NO3)3 solution (2mgmL−1) and dried under an infrared lamp. The obtained powders were calcined at 500°C for 4h. Unless otherwise stated, the nominal Rh contents were 1.0wt.%, and the actual values were determined by ICP. 2.2 Characterization XRD patterns were recorded on a MSAL XD2 X-ray diffractometer using CuKα radiation at 40kV and 30mA with a scanning speed of 4°min−1. BET surface areas and pore volumes were measured on a Micromeritics Tristar 3000 instrument. The samples were pretreated at 300°C under vacuum for 3h, followed by N2 adsorption at −196°C. Field-emission SEM images were recorded on Nova NanoSEM 450. TEM data were recorded with a JEM-2011F instrument (Jeol). The Rh contents were determined by inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES) using a Perkin–Elmer Optima 8000. XPS spectra were recorded on a Shimadzu/Kratos AXIS Ultra DLD spectrometer with AlKα radiation as the excitation source. The C 1s line (284.6eV) was used as the reference to calibrate the binding energy. Rh2O3 dispersion was determined using a pulsed technique of CO chemisorption on a Micromeritics AutoChem II instrument loaded with 0.15g catalyst (40−60mesh), based on 1:1 stoichiometry (CO/Rh). The catalyst was pretreated in He flow at 400°C for 1h, and cooled to 30°C. Then, a pulse of 5% CO-He mixture was repeatedly injected into the reactor via a six-way valve until the CO signals from the thermal conductivity detector remained constant. He was used as the carrier gas. The volume of CO chemisorbed was determined by summing the fractions of CO consumed in each pulse. CO2 −TPD experiments were conducted on a Micromeritics AutoChem II instrument with a TCD detector. 0.3g HAP sample (40−60mesh) was preheated in He at 500°C for 1h, and cooled to 80°C in He. The sample was exposed to 5% CO2/He (30mLmin−1) for 1h, and swept by He flow at 80°C for 1.5h. Finally, the sample was heated to 500°C at a ramping rate of 10°Cmin−1. Temperature programmed desorption of oxygen (O2 −TPD) was performed on a FINESORB-3010 instrument. In each case, 0.2g catalyst (40−60mesh) was pretreated with He (30mLmin−1) at 500°C for 1h and then cooled down to 50°C. The sample was exposed to O2 (10mLmin−1) at 50°C for 1h, swept in He flow (30mLmin−1) for 3h, and heated in He to 550°C at a rate of 10°Cmin−1. 2.3 Catalytic tests Catalytic activity of N2O decomposition was tested in a fixed bed reactor [61−67]. 0.5g catalyst (40−60mesh) was packed in an U-shaped glass tube (inner diameter: 7mm) sealed by quartz wool. A gas stream of 0.5% N2O (balanced by He) flowed through the catalyst at a rate of 60mLmin−1. The GHSV was 7000h−1, unless otherwise stated. The catalyst (first kept at near room temperature) was exposed to the gas stream for 0.5h, during which the existing stream was periodically analyzed by a gas chromatograph (GC, Agilent 7890A) with GC columns (Sepuco 6ftQ and Sepuco Q&5A, column temperature: 80°C) that can separate N2O, O2, and N2. The reaction temperature was then varied using a furnace and kept at various elevated temperature for 0.5h in each temperature step. The exhaust was again periodically analyzed by the GC, and the conversion of N2O was calculated according to X=([N2O]in −[N2O]out)/[N2O]in, where [N2O]in refers to the N2O concentration or peak area at room temperature, and [N2O]out refers to the N2O concentration or peak area at an elevated temperature. To study the effect of O2 and/or H2O vapor on Rh/HAP-PEG-200, 5% O2 and/or 2% H2O were added into the reaction mixture, whereas the concentration of N2O was still 0.5%, and the total flow rate of the reaction mixture was still 60mLmin−1. A N2O pulse response experiment was carried out using a mass spectrometer [69]. Before the pulse response experiment, 50mg catalyst was pretreated at 240°C for 1h in 2%N2O/He to reach a steady state. After sweeping the He for 0.5h, a 2% N2O/He pulse was periodically injected, and the response was followed using a mass spectrometer. 3 Results 3.1 Structural and physical properties of HAP and Rh/HAP samples Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of Rh/HAP catalysts prepared by using different HAP supports. All XRD patterns are consistent with the standard pattern of HAP (PDF#09-0432). Primary peaks located at 25.9, 31.7, 32.2, 32.9, 34.0, 46.7, and 49.5° can be assigned to the (002), (211), (112), (300), (202), (222), and (213) planes of HAP, respectively. On the other hand, Rh species (Rh or Rh2O3) are not detectable, probably due to their low content and high dispersion. Note that Rh/HAP-PEG-200 and Rh/HAP-EDTA-200 show sharper peaks (i.e., higher crystallinity) than Rh/HAP-EDTA-100 and Rh/HAP-normal, as explained by the high temperature (200°C) used in the hydrothermal synthesis of HAP supports. In addition, the (112)/(211) peak intensity ratios of Rh/HAP-PEG-200 and Rh/HAP-EDTA-200 (both <0.7) are lower than those of Rh/HAP-EDTA-100 and Rh/HAP-normal (both about 0.9, Table 1 ), implying the existence of some differences in the micro-morphology of HAP supports [70]. Fig. 2 shows the SEM images of Rh/HAP samples. The SEM images merely show the morphologies of HAP supports, and supported Rh2O3 particles cannot be distinguished with the low resolution. The surface morphologies of HAP-PEG-200, HAP-EDTA-200, and HAP-EDTA-100 synthesized hydrothermally are more ordered than that of HAP-normal. In particular, HAP-PEG-200 and HAP-EDTA-200 have many rods whereas HAP-EDTA-100 has many stubs or particles. However, HAP-normal shows a high degree of disorder, in terms of both shape and size. Fig. 3 shows the TEM images of the supported catalysts. Again, Rh2O3 particles still cannot be seen clearly with the relatively low resolution, but the morphologies of the HAP supports are clear. The average sizes of HAP-PEG-200, HAP-EDTA-200, HAP-EDTA-100, and HAP-normal are estimated to be 30×117, 25×93, 18×45, and 19×57nm, respectively, by measuring the sizes of 100HAP particles for each sample. The average length-diameter ratios of these samples are 3.9, 3.7, 2.5, and 3.0, respectively. These results mean that a higher synthesis temperature would enhance the anisotropism of HAP [71–73]. In addition, a high synthesis temperature would lead to big particle sizes of HAP, consistent with the high crystallinity (probed by XRD data in Fig. 1) and smaller surface areas (Table 1). As shown in Figs. S1 and S2 in the Supporting Information, the HAP supports have mesopores and marcopores. These pores may originate from the interspace among HAP rods/particles. The pore volumes of HAP-PEG-200, HAP-EDTA-200, HAP-EDTA-100, and HAP-normal are 0.318, 0.270, 0.353, and 0.132cm3 g−1, respectively (Table 1). Fig. 4 shows the TEM images of Rh/HAP catalysts with higher resolution. With this resolution, Rh2O3 particles and details of the HAP supports can be seen clearly. All HAP samples exhibit parallel lines with a distance of 0.82nm with each other, meaning that the HAP (010) plane (with six equivalent surfaces due to P63/m symmetry [73]) is the dominating crystal face and particles tend to elongate along c-axis for HAP samples synthesized hydrothermally. The result is in accordance with previous studies on crystal terminal [74,75] and crystal growth orientation [68,76]. The size distributions of Rh2O3 particles are determined by analyzing 300 particles in each sample. For all Rh/HAP catalysts, the sizes of most (above ca. 80%) Rh2O3 particles are in the range of 0.5 and 1.25nm (Fig. S3). The average Rh2O3 particle sizes are almost the same for different catalysts (from 0.91 to 0.98nm, Table 2 ), consistent with the absence of Rh2O3 peaks in XRD patterns. On the other hand, the Rh2O3 dispersion measured by CO chemisorption is always near 50% for different catalysts (Table 2). 3.2 Activities of different Rh/HAP catalysts After reporting the fundamental structural and physical properties of HAP and Rh/HAP samples characterized by regular methods, we turn to the important difference in the catalytic performance of Rh/HAP catalysts in N2O decomposition. The catalytic activities were first tested as a function of reaction temperature. As shown in Fig. 5 , the catalytic activities of catalysts follow the sequence of Rh/HAP-PEG–200>Rh/HAP-EDTA-200≈Rh/HAP-normal>Rh/HAP-EDTA-100, considering the relative positions of the conversion curves, the N2O conversions at a same temperature, or the T50 (temperature required for 50% conversion) values (223, 242, 248, and 272°C, respectively). The nominal Rh loading was set to be 1.0wt.%, by controlling the amounts of Rh(NO3)3 and HAP during impregnation. As shown in Table 2, the Rh contents (measured by ICP) of catalysts are in the range of 0.93−1.03wt.%. The N2O conversions over Rh/HAP-PEG-200, Rh/HAP-EDTA-200, Rh/HAP-normal, and Rh/HAP-EDTA-100 at 225°C are 53.7%, 16.4%, 12.8%, and 3.8%, respectively. Considering the actual Rh contents, we calculate the specific rates (expressed as moles of N2O converted per mole of Rh per hour) of these catalysts at 225°C as 8.39, 2.67, 1.88, and 0.60h−1, respectively. The most active Rh/HAP-PEG-200 is much more active than Rh/SiO2, Rh/Al2O3, and Rh/TiO2 tested under the same reaction conditions [21] (Fig. S4). Rh/CeO2 is a benchmark catalyst in the literature [42]. We additionally prepared several Rh/CeO2 catalysts by using CeO2 supports prepared by different methods [77]. As shown in Fig. S5, Rh/HAP-PEG-200 is more active than the least active Rh/CeO2 in this study, and almost the same active as the most active Rh/CeO2. The high activity of Rh/HAP-PEG-200 does not come directly from the support because the support is not active for N2O decomposition (Fig. S6). Fig. S6 also shows that Rh/HAP-PEG-200 is active even if the Rh content is as low as 0.1wt.%. As the Rh content is increased, the N2O conversion on Rh/HAP-PEG-200 at a specific reaction temperature (e.g., 250°C) increases and the T50 value decreases. The T50 values of Rh/HAP-PEG-200 catalysts with 0.1wt.%, 0.5wt.%, and 1wt.% Rh loadings are 312, 263, and 223°C, respectively. The most active Rh/HAP-PEG-200 was selected to study the influence of co-feed O2, H2O, and/or CO2. O2, H2O, and CO2 are often present in the reaction mixture in practical applications [54,57]. Here the volume concentrations of co-feed O2, H2O, and CO2 are set to be 5%, 2%, and 2%, respectively. As shown in Fig. 6 , the presence of O2 or CO2 shows an inhibiting effect, as the T50 value increases from 223°C (in the absence of co-feed O2 or CO2) to 252 or 267°C in the presence of 5% O2 or 2% CO2. The inhibiting effect of H2O is more obvious, as the T50 value becomes 333°C in the presence of 2% H2O. The presence of both 5% O2 and 2% H2O makes the T50 value become 344°C. The inhibition by O2 and H2O is general for Rh-based catalysts in N2O decomposition, due to the competitive adsorption of O2 and H2O on the active sites [45,78]. The presence of 5% O2, 2% H2O, and 2% CO2 makes the T50 value becomes 360°C. Similar inhibiting effects are observed for Rh/CeO2-nanooct. As shown in Fig. S7, the activity decreases very obviously in the presence of 5% O2 and 2% H2O, and the presence of 5% O2, 2% H2O, and 2% CO2 makes the T50 value becomes 352°C, 8°C lower than the T50 of Rh/HAP-PEG-200 tested under the same condition. Fig. S8 shows the influence of different GHSV values (7000, 14,000, and 23,300h−1, achieved by loading 0.50, 0.25, and 0.15g catalyst in the reactor, respectively) on the catalytic performance of Rh/HAP-PEG-200 with 1wt.% Rh. The reaction was carried out in 0.5% N2O, without co-feeding O2, H2O, or CO2. In general, a higher GHSV leads to a decrease of N2O conversion at the same reaction temperature. The T50 values are 223, 241, and 258°C at GHSV of 7000, 14,000, and 23,300h−1, respectively. It is reasonable to understand that the T50 value increases at higher GHSV, because less catalyst is put into the reactor. Even when the GHSV is as high as 23,300h−1, the N2O conversion still reaches 91.7% at 300°C. The influence of GHSV values on the catalytic activity of Rh/HAP-PEG-200 was also tested in the presence of 5% O2, 2% H2O, and 2% CO2. As shown in Fig. S9, the T50 values are 361, 378, and 390°C at GHSV of 7000, 14,000, and 23,300h−1, respectively. The stability of Rh/HAP-PEG-200 was also studied as a function of reaction time. As shown in Fig. S10, the catalyst has good stability at 245°C, in the absence of co-feed O2 or H2O. In the presence of 5% O2 and 2% H2O, the catalyst is less active (Fig. 6), so the stability was tested at 400°C (in the presence of 5% O2 and 2% H2O). As shown in Fig. S11a, the catalyst reaches a steady N2O conversion of 97%. After the stability test, the catalyst was cooled down, and the activity of the spent catalyst was measured in the absence of O2 and H2O, as a function of reaction temperature. As shown in Fig. S11b, the activity is the same as that of the fresh catalyst without undergoing the stability test involving 5% O2 and 2% H2O, implying that no structural change occurs during the stability test at 400°C and the inhibiting effect of O2 and H2O is reversible (i.e., the activity is restored after O2 and H2O are retracted). The stability of Rh/HAP-PEG-200 in the presence of 5% O2 and 2% H2O was also tested at a higher temperature. Before the stability test, the activity of Rh/HAP-PEG-200 in the presence of 5% O2 and 2% H2O was tested as a function of reaction temperature at a high GHSV of 23,300h−1, in order to choose a suitable reaction temperature for the stability test. As shown in Fig. S12, the activity of the catalyst in the presence of 5% O2 and 2% H2O is lower than that in the absence of O2 and H2O, achieving 99% N2O conversion at 460°C. We then tested the stability of a fresh Rh/HAP-PEG-200 catalyst in the presence of 5% O2 and 2% H2O at a high GHSV of 23,300h−1 at 460°C. As shown in Fig. S13a, the catalyst reaches a steady N2O conversion of 98%. After the stability test, the catalyst was cooled down, and the activity was measured in the absence of O2 and H2O. As shown in Fig. S13b, the activity of the spent catalyst is slightly lower that the fresh catalyst without undergoing the stability test when the reaction temperature is in the range of 225−275°C, and the activity is completely restored when the reaction temperature is above 300°C. The stability of Rh/HAP-PEG-200 in the presence of O2, H2O, and CO2 was also studied at 500°C, at a high GHSV of 23,300h−1. According to Fig. S9, the N2O conversion in the presence of 2% H2O, 5% O2, and 2% CO2 reaches 99% at 500°C, at a high GHSV of 23,300h−1. The N2O conversion is close to 100% during the stability test (Fig. S14a), and the activity of the spent catalyst (tested in the presence of 2% H2O, 5% O2, and 2% CO2) is slightly lower that the fresh catalyst without undergoing the stability test, as the T50 values of the spent catalyst and the fresh catalyst are 390 and 403°C, respectively (Fig. S14b). As revealed by TEM characterization (Fig. S15b), slight sintering of Rh2O3 particles may be the reason for the decrease in activity. The average size of Rh2O3 particles increases from 0.91nm before reaction to 1.14nm after the stability test at 500°C (Fig. S16). However, there is no evidence for the phase transition or sintering of the HAP support, as proved by TEM (Fig. S15a) and XRD (Fig. S17) data. 3.3 Chemical properties of HAP and Rh/HAP samples After demonstrating that the catalytic activities of the catalysts are quite different, we now present additional characterization data to reveal the reasons for the difference in the catalytic activity. Fig. 7 shows the Rh 3d XPS spectra of Rh/HAP catalysts. Two sets of peaks located at 306–311eV and 311–317eV are assigned to Rh 3d5/2 and Rh 3d3/2, respectively. We will interpret the data according to Rh 3d5/2 peaks due to their higher intensity. The peak corresponding to Rh3+ is located at 308.3–310.5eV while that of Rh° is located at 307.0–307.7eV [45,79]. As shown in Fig. 7, each Rh catalyst shows a peak located at 309.2eV, representing Rh3+, while the peak at 307.7eV is ignorable (below 5%). Therefore, Rh species exist mainly as Rh2O3, which is reasonable because the catalysts were calcined in air at 500°C but not reduced. Surface Ca/P ratios of Rh/HAP catalysts, measured by XPS, are listed in Table 3 . Both Rh/HAP-PEG-200 and Rh/HAP-normal have a Ca/P ratio of 1.46, close to the surface stoichiometric ratio of 1.50 (in contrast to the bulk stoichiometric ratio of 1.67) [1]. The surface Ca/P ratios of Rh/HAP-EDTA-200 and Rh/HAP-EDTA-100 are 1.35 and 1.34, indicating the formation of non-stoichiometric HAP due to the complexion of Ca2+ by EDTA during the synthesis [80]. Fig. 8 shows the O 1s XPS spectra of Rh/HAP catalysts. The main peak at ca. 530.8eV is ascribed to lattice oxygen, and a shoulder peak at ca. 532.9eV is assigned to hydroxyl oxygen [76]. The XPS data are deconvoluted to estimate the relative percentage of hydroxyl oxygen (among all oxygen species). As shown in Table 3, the relative percentage of hydroxyl on Rh/HAP-PEG-200 is 31.0%, much higher than that on Rh/HAP-normal (16.8%). Rh/HAP-EDTA-200 and Rh/HAP-EDTA-100 show lower relative percentages of hydroxyl (11.4% and 13.0%, respectively). Fig. 9 shows the CO2 −TPD profiles of HAP supports. All HAP samples exhibit two CO2 desorption peaks, corresponding to two kinds of basic sites with different strengths. The stronger basic sites are more abundant than the weaker basic sites (as judged by the relative peak areas), consistent with previous findings [81,82]. As shown in Table 3, the amounts of basic sites of samples follow the sequence of HAP-PEG–200>HAP-EDTA-200 ≈ HAP-normal>HAP-EDTA-100. As judged by the peak temperatures of high temperature peaks (Fig. 9), the basic strengths of samples follow the sequence of HAP-EDTA–200>HAP-PEG–200>HAP-normal>HAP-EDTA-100. The results are in line with previous findings that hydroxyl groups could act as basic sites [73] and non-stoichiometric HAP showed lower alkalinity [1]. In addition, HAP-normal has broader desorption peaks, probably due to higher degree of disorder in terms of shape and size of the HAP support. Fig. 10 shows the O2 −TPD profiles of Rh/HAP catalysts. All the samples exhibit a broad asymmetric peak, starting at 189, 193, 209 and 215°C for Rh/HAP-EDTA-100, Rh/HAP-EDTA-200, Rh/HAP-normal and Rh/HAP-PEG-200, respectively. It is obvious that the amounts of desorbed O2 follow the sequence of Rh/HAP-EDTA–100>Rh/HAP-normal≈Rh/HAP-EDTA–200>Rh/HPA-PEG-200 (Table 3), inversely correlated with the activity sequence of these catalysts. 4 Discussion 4.1 Synthesis and properties of HAP supports In this work, we synthesized HAP supports by different methods and under different conditions. HAP-PEG-200 was prepared hydrothermally in the presence of PEG600 additive at 200°C. HAP-EDTA-200 and HAP-EDTA-100 were prepared hydrothermally in the presence of Na2-EDTA additive at 200 and 100°C, respectively. HAP-normal was prepared by a conventional precipitation method. According to SEM images in Fig. 2, HAP-PEG-200 and HAP-EDTA-200 have many rods whereas HAP-EDTA-100 has many stubs or particles. HAP-normal shows a high degree of disorder, in terms of both shape and size. The average sizes of HAP-PEG-200, HAP-EDTA-200, HAP-EDTA-100, and HAP-normal are 30×117, 25×93, 18×45, and 19×57nm, respectively (Fig. 3). Therefore, a higher synthesis temperature would make the formed HAP particles bigger and longer. According to high-resolution TEM images in Fig. 4, the HAP (010) plane is the dominating crystal face and particles tend to elongate along c-axis for HAP samples synthesized hydrothermally. This is consistent with the conclusion in a recent theoretical study [73]. Higher hydrothermal temperature could accelerate precipitation-dissolution equilibrium, which is favorable for forming the most stable (010) plane. The presence of additives may also influence the Ca/P ratios of HAP samples. As shown in Table 3, the surface Ca/P ratios of Rh/HAP-PEG-200 and Rh/HAP-normal are both 1.46, whereas those of Rh/HAP-EDTA-200 and Rh/HAP-EDTA-100 are lower (1.35 and 1.34, respectively). The formation of HAP could be regarded as a Ca2+ absorbing process, resulting in continuous phase change of the precipitation. However, for EDTA assisted samples, high EDTA dosage (with an EDTA/Ca2+ ratio of 0.6) and a stable complex formation may cause competition between the precipitation and complexation to strive Ca2+, making the chemical equilibrium of Ca2+ deposition move towards the adverse reaction. As a result, non-stoichiometric HAP samples with lower Ca/P ratios are formed in the presence of EDTA. 4.2 Different activities of Rh/HAP catalysts The catalytic activities of four catalysts follow the sequence of Rh/HAP-PEG-200>Rh/HAP-EDTA-200 ≈ Rh/HAP-normal>Rh/EDTA-100 (Fig. 5). The Rh contents of these catalysts are determined by ICP as 0.97, 0.93, 1.03, and 0.96wt.%, respectively, all close to the nominal value of 1.0wt.% (Table 2). TEM data indicate that Rh2O3 nanoparticles disperse homogeneously on the supports, and the average sizes are 0.91, 0.98, 0.92, and 0.96nm, respectively. The Rh2O3 dispersions on these catalysts are similar (Fig. S3, Table 2). XPS data confirm that Rh species exist mainly in the form of Rh2O3. Therefore, the difference in catalytic activity is not due to the difference in the Rh content and the average size of Rh2O3 particles. As revealed by O2–TPD, the amounts of oxygen desorbed from different catalysts follow the sequence of Rh/HAP-PEG-200<Rh/HAP-EDTA-200≈Rh/HAP-normal<Rh/EDTA-100 (Fig. 10, Table 3), inversely correlating with the N2O decomposition activity. It is generally accepted that O2 desorption is the rate-determining step in N2O decomposition over Rh catalysts [59,60,78,83]. If oxygen cannot be smoothly desorbed from catalysts surface, the active sites will be occupied, leading to the inhibition of N2O decomposition. Here the most active catalyst (i.e., Rh/HAP-PEG-200) shows the smallest O2 desorption peak, implying that it can adsorb the least amount of O2 among these catalysts. This is in line with the highest activity of this catalyst. As revealed by CO2–TPD, the amounts of basic sites on these catalysts follow the sequence of Rh/HAP-PEG-200>Rh/HAP-EDTA-200≈Rh/HAP-normal>Rh/EDTA-100 (Table 3), correlating nicely with the activity sequence, i.e., the most active catalyst has the greatest amount of basic sites. In the literature, basicity of a catalyst is often found to be helpful for N2O decomposition [50,51,84]. It was reported that the electronic properties of metal oxides could be modified by alkali doping [85], further promoting the redox properties of metal oxides [86,87] and/or weakening the oxygen binding energy [88], which is beneficial for N2O decomposition. Our previous study indicated that Rh/HAP is a good catalyst for N2O decomposition because it has rich basic sites [21]. Here we further found that the basicity of Rh/HAP can be further adjusted by preparation methods and parameters. The question now arises as why the most active Rh/HAP-PEG-200 catalyst has the largest amount of basic sites. We believe this is due to the preferential exposure of HAP (010) plane on HAP-PEG-200’s ordered rods, as proved by high-resolution TEM images (Fig. 4). Comparing with other terminals (e.g., (001) surface of Ca4(PO4)3(OH)2, Ca-exposed (010) surface of Ca4(PO4)2, and PO4-exposed (010) surface of Ca4(PO4)2), the most stable OH-terminated HAP (010) surface has a formula of Ca2(PO4)2(OH)2, with a high density of electron rich oxygen in OH− and PO4 3− that can act as Lewis bases and a less amount of electron poor Ca2+ [1,73]. The presence of more hydroxyls on Rh/HAP-PEG-200 is demonstrated by XPS (Table 3). Another factor that may influence the basicity of HAP is Ca/P ratio. A stoichiometirc HAP sample has a formula of Ca10(PO4)6(OH)2, i.e., the Ca/P ratio is 1.67. A non-stoichiometirc HAP sample has a formula of Ca10−x (HPO4) x (PO4)6−x (OH)2−x (0<x<1), i.e., Ca/P ratio is below 1.67. Non-stoichiometirc HAP has less Ca2+, less PO4 3−, less OH−, and more HPO4 2− in the HAP lattice than stoichiometirc HAP [1,80]. Electron-rich OH− and PO4 3− can act as bases [73], whereas proton-containing HPO4 2− can act as an acid. According to the formula of non-stoichiometirc HAP, the proportions of OH− and PO4 3− in the HAP lattice decrease as the Ca/P ratio decreases, and the proportion of HPO4 2− increases accordingly. Thus, weaker basicity is exhibited for HAP with a lower Ca/P ratio [1]. In our work, HAP-EDTA-200 and HAP-EDTA-100 have lower surface Ca/P values (1.35 and 1.34, respectively, Table 3) and weaker intensity of hydroxyl oxygen (Fig. 8 and Table 3), resulting in lower number of basic sites (46.1 and 24.9μmol/g, respectively, Table 3). 4.3 Limitation and future work The objective of this work was to find the correlation among preparation methods/conditions, physicochemical properties, and catalytic performance of Rh/HAP catalysts in N2O decomposition. Rh/HAP-PEG-200 was found to be the most active among Rh/HAP catalysts, in the catalytic decomposition of 0.5% N2O. The influence of co-feed O2, CO2, and H2O was studied using this catalyst. It should be mentioned that the gas composition in industrial settings is more complex, often including NO, SO2, etc. [55–58]. For future applications, it is desirable to further study the influence of co-feed NO, SO2 etc. The development of the Rh/HAP catalyst system also provides a new opportunity for studying the reaction mechanism in the future. Our preliminary N2O pulse experiments involving Rh/HAP-PEG-200 show the simultaneous generation of N2 and O2 (Fig. S18), thus providing evidence for the possibility of the “N2O+O*→N2 +O2 +*” step [39], consistent with the N2O decomposition mechanism on Rh/Al2O3 studied using tracer technique [42]. Nevertheless, additional experiments are still needed in the future to uncover the reaction mechanism. 5 Conclusions Rh/HAP-PEG-200, Rh/HAP-EDTA-200, and Rh/HAP-EDTA-100 catalysts were prepared using hydroxyapatite (HAP) supports prepared hydrothermally at 200 or 100°C in the presence of PEG or EDTA additives. For comparison, Rh/HAP-normal was prepared by loading Rh(NO3)3 onto a conventional HAP support. Different preparation methods influence the micro-morphology of HAP. The hydrothermal method leads to the formation of HAP nanorods. OH-terminated (010) crystal plane is the dominantly exposed surface of HAP supports. The catalytic activities of catalysts follow the sequence of Rh/HAP-PEG-200>Rh/HAP-EDTA-200≈Rh/HAP-normal>Rh/EDTA-100, which is correlated with the amounts of surface hydroxyls, the basicity, and O2 that can be adsorbed onto the catalysts. Surface hydroxyls and basic sites seem to be beneficial for the reaction, whereas the amounts of adsorbed O2 inversely correlate with the N2O decomposition activity. Acknowledgements W. Hua and Y. coredata.dc:description: Three hydroxyapatite (HAP) supported rhodium catalysts (i.e., Rh/HAP-PEG-200, Rh/HAP-EDTA-200, and Rh/HAP-EDTA-100) were prepared by loading Rh(NO3)3 onto HAP supports prepared hydrothermally at 200 or 100°C in the presence of PEG or EDTA additive, followed by calcination at 500°C. For comparison, an additional Rh/HAP-normal catalyst was prepared using a conventional HAP support prepared by precipitation. Different preparation methods/conditions were found to influence the physicochemical properties (e.g., micro-morphology, basicity, concentration of surface hydroxyls, oxygen-desorption property) of HAP supports and/or Rh/HAP catalysts. The activities of these catalysts in N2O decomposition follow the sequence of Rh/HAP-PEG-200>Rh/HAP-EDTA-200≈Rh/HAP-normal>Rh/EDTA-100. The correlation among preparation methods/conditions, physicochemical properties, and catalytic performance of Rh/HAP catalysts was investigated in detail.
coredata.dc:title: Correlation among preparation methods/conditions, physicochemical properties, and catalytic performance of Rh/hydroxyapatite catalysts in N2O decomposition
coredata.prism:publicationName: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical
